title.narrative: Amhara Region Filter Programme 2021

description.narrative: Aqua for All has found an efficioent and effective way to create a market for water filters in Amhara Region. Utilities in 4 zones have taken up the responsibility for safe water at home and manage the logistics around filter sales to clients and non-clients. Aqua for All is aiming to transfer its project management role to the Association of Water Utilities in Amhara, for which it is assisted by a group of local consultants. Meanwhile, the sales of filters is further expanded.
Scale - Drinking water
5003 Hrs Waithera Kinyeki
5003 hrs Gashaye
Agregation small costs
Office costs 2021 Ethiopia

title.narrative: Project photo
S2- Local partners provide safe sanitation products and services

description.narrative: Disaggregate this number at 3 levels

title.narrative: S2.1- Total number and type of safe and functional individual toilets / containment units provided (specified by nr of seats per type of facilities

description.narrative: Fill in number of toilets and containment units provided per type selected here. Calculate in nr of seats/drop holes or stances

title.narrative: D2- Local partners provide safe and functional water products and services

description.narrative: Total number of new users served by the initiative with access to Safe drinking water

title.narrative: D2.2- Average volume of water sold by initiative per day in litres

description.narrative: Number of litres water used and sold on average per day. (Calculated over a period of at least 1 month and preferably 3 months) Divide total volume by nr of days calculated. E.g if volume is measured, divide monthly volume by nr of days per month.

title.narrative: D2.1- Total number of safe and functional Water facilities made available

description.narrative: Provide total number of water facilities per type of facility (Nr of tap points per type) produced and provided by the initiative to users at time of measurement. Choose from list.

title.narrative: 5- Local partners and targeted groups build capacity in wash business development, technical knowledge, life skills and partnerships for local businesses.

description.narrative: Total number of people reached with capacity building, training and learning events, disaggregated by gender and by type of event

title.narrative: 5.1- Total number of people reached with capacity building in wash business development, technical knowledge, life skills and partnerships for local businesses.

description.narrative: Fill in total number of people currently reached with capacity building activities by the initiative, based upon documentation. Disaggregate Male/Female and disaggregate per type of event and provide nr of people per event.

title.narrative: 2- Increased employment opportunities for local community
2.1-Number of people that have a paid position or have become self employed (e.g entrepeneurs) as a result of the initiative.

description.narrative:
Total nr of individuals that have gained a position as a result of initiative at this time of measurement . Disaggregate by number of new jobs created and number of entrepreneurs/self-employed positions. Disaggregate by male/female.
\*\* Minimum requirement to the reporting indicator should follow National standards on daily wages and working conditions (Max 8 hours per day and max 6 days a week)
​

title.narrative: 6- Local partners have viable business models and/or ensured long-term financial sustainability
6.2- Total number of current paying individual customers per month (average)

description.narrative:
Fill in Number of individual customers that paid for the initiative's products or services. (AVERAGE PER MONTH) calculated over past 3-12 months.
\* Note to enumerator/pm: One customer usually provides one household with a product or service (Average 4/5 persons depending on demographics) Please take this along in analysis.

comment.narrative: Fil in number of paying customers as an average per month calculated over past 3-12 months.

title.narrative: 6.1a- Net profit margin as a percentage over time (6-months/year)

description.narrative:
Determine the number of separate operational/business units./organizations. This means the revenue generating operations of the program that will remain after program ending or separate business units that are operating under the program. In case of a franchise or connected operation falling under the same initiative you may aggregate the data and fill in one unit only
_Calculate Net profit Margin as a Percentage: Net Profit margin = Net Profit ⁄ Total revenue x 100. Net profit is calculated by deducting all company expenses from its total revenue. The result of the profit margin calculation is a percentage – for example, a 10% profit margin means for each $1 of revenue the company earns $0.10 in net profit. Revenue represents the total sales of the company in a period. Calculate over minimum of 6 months._

title.narrative: 6.1b- Cost recovery percentage: Percentage of annual cost of operation that is currently covered with annual income.

description.narrative: _Extra financial indicator for Via Water projects and start-ups under the response facility. _Calculate this by dividing the total annual income by total annual costs of the operation x 100. into a cost recovery percentage. Thus, answer the question, what percentage of annual costs are currently covered with income. Calculate this including staff costs and cost of depreciation, loans and savings for CAPEX.

title.narrative: 6.3- Current stage of innovation

description.narrative: Select current stage of your innovation/initiative

title.narrative: I2- Increased availability of water in the area of operation
I2.1- Volume of all water retained by the initiative (m3)

description.narrative: First choose type of water source where water is retained and then fill in the amount of water in M3 per year. Total volume of water retained by the initiative (m3) per year. Use M3 per year!!

title.narrative: S4- Initiatives are socially inclusive and integrate hygiene, safety and gender elements into their programs
S4.1- Number of functional handwashing facilities provided with access to water, soap or other disinfectant

description.narrative: Total number of handwashing facilities provided by the initiative for users. Disaggregate per type of user School/ domestic/Public. (this includes fixed facilities [sinks / taps]; mobile object [buckets / jug / kettle]) NO WATER OR SOAP/DESFINCENTANT MEANS NOT FUNCTIONAL! (Note to PM: To quantify access into nr users: For domestic = 20 users per facility; For public and schools = max 200 users per facility)

title.narrative: S4.2- Please indicate what interventions and/or facilities the program has provided to cater for 1) Hygiene and Menstrual Hygiene Management and 2) People with disabilities and 3) Gender: women and girl safety?

description.narrative:
Provide a short summary of the facilities or interventions currently provided on the following 3 topics.
1) Hygiene education and Menstrual Hygiene management. (e.g washrooms, MHM facilities, education, cleaning schedules etc)
2) In what way does the solution take people with disabilities into account. Especially toilets need to be accessible for people with disabilities.
3) How does the program currently integrate gender elements into the program. Focus on women and girl participation, privacy and safety elements

title.narrative: S5- Time saved for women a daily basis as a result of improved sanitation
S5.1- What is the average time taken per day in minutes by women for sanitation of themselves and their children/ dependent family

description.narrative:
What is the average time taken per day in minutes for women for sanitation of themselves and their children/ dependent family. Fill in number - average time (minutes) per day. This indicator will be used to calculate the economic cost of safe sanitation for women users using an Aqua for All-commissioned SROI model (from Equilo). It indicates financial savings as a result of time savings from sanitation at home for women - who generally assume main responsibility for health and disease
(Preferably time use surveys should be utilized at the beginning and end of the support period to determine the average time spent (in minutes) by women users for sanitation in general.)
​

title.narrative: 1- Improved access to safe water, sanitation and IWRM services/products
1 - Total number of people reached with safe Water, sanitation and IWRM services/products

description.narrative: Fill in the total number of people reached with your initiative at this exact time of measurement (beneficiaries, customers, users etc) with all of the Water, sanitation and IWRM activities. number of users (Aggregate nr of beneficiaries under drinking water, sanitation and IWRM and Capacity building)

comment.narrative: Baseline data collected at project level

title.narrative: I1- Total number of current unique users served by the initiative with IWRM products/services

description.narrative:
Fill in total number of current users for IWRM that are male and female
Fill the number of these users that are Domestic/School users, Public users
As this level has links with sanitation or drinking water. use the indicators D1 or S1 with their detailed descriptions to determine the service level

title.narrative: S1- Total number of current unique users served by the initiative with access to improved and safe sanitation products and services

description.narrative:
Fill in total number of unique current users for sanitation. Disaggregated per: Male/Female. Type: Domestic users (private and households), school users and for other public users (e.g markets and hospitals, communal users etc)
Finally disaggregate users that are provided with a Safely managed / Basic service / Limited service from the initiative. The initiative must tick all criteria to be considered as that service level.
1) Safely managed service:
- the initiative provides an improved sanitation facility (this includes: flush/pour flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs)
- the initiative's sanitation service is not shared with other households
- the initiative ensures that human excreta are safely disposed in situ or transported and treated off-site
2) Basic service:
- the initiative provides an improved sanitation facility (this includes: flush/pour flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs)
- the initiative's sanitation facility is not shared with other households
- initiative does not ensure that human excreta and urine is safely disposed / transported / treated
3) Limited service: Usually at baseline level, but cannot be included at target level. This includes, open pits, unimproved pit latrines, unlined pits, no slabs, prone to flooding etc
\* This is indicative of the reach and scale of the initiative in reaching new users with its products and services in terms of the service level that is being provided (as defined by JMP).

title.narrative: D1 - Total number of current unique users served by the initiative with sustainable access to improved and safe drinking water products and services

description.narrative:
Total nr of beneficiaries disaggregated by Male/Female and Domestic/school/public users
Please also check the criteria per service level to see what level best matches your initiative. The initiative must fulfill all criteria to be considered at that service level.
1. Safely managed service: 2. the initiative provides an improved source of water (this includes: piped water, boreholes or tube wells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, packaged / bottled water, water that is delivered) 3. the initiative is located on the premises of the household or dwelling 4. the initiative provides drinking water whenever it is needed 5. the drinking water provided by the initiative has no presence of E.coli 6. the drinking water provided by the initiative contains no / limited levels of arsenic and fluoride (below WHO standards: < 0.01 mg/L arsenic and < 1.5mg/L fluoride 7. Basic service: 8. the initiative provides an improved source of water (this includes: piped water, boreholes or tube wells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, packaged / bottled water, water that is delivered) 9. the initiative provides water for users where the collection time is less than 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing 0. Limited service:
Drinking water from an improved source for which collection time exceeds 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing.
1. Unimproved service:
Drinking water from an unprotected dug well or unprotected spring
\* This is indicative of the reach and scale of the initiative in reaching new users with its products and services in terms of the service level that is being provided (as defined by JMP).

title.narrative: D1E - Total number of current unique users served by the initiative with sustainable access to improved and safe drinking water products and services

description.narrative:
Total nr of beneficiaries disaggregated by Male/Female and Domestic/school/public users
Please also check the criteria per service level to see what level best matches your initiative. The initiative must fulfill all criteria to be considered at that service level.
1. Safely managed service:
- the initiative provides an improved source of water (this includes: piped water, boreholes or tube wells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, packaged / bottled water, water that is delivered)
- the initiative is located on the premises of the household or dwelling
- the initiative provides drinking water whenever it is needed
- the drinking water provided by the initiative has no presence of E.coli
- the drinking water provided by the initiative contains no / limited levels of arsenic and fluoride (below WHO standards: < 0.01 mg/L arsenic and < 1.5mg/L fluoride
2. Basic service:
- the initiative provides an improved source of water (this includes: piped water, boreholes or tube wells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, packaged / bottled water, water that is delivered)
- the initiative provides water for users where the collection time is less than 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing
3. Limited service:
Drinking water from an improved source for which collection time exceeds 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing.
4. Unimproved service:
Drinking water from an unprotected dug well or unprotected spring
\* This is indicative of the reach and scale of the initiative in reaching new users with its products and services in terms of the service level that is being provided (as defined by JMP).

title.narrative: Other indicators (P) and narrative explanation

S3- Human waste is safely disposed, treated, re-used and/or sold
